name: 勞維俊
objective:
This course examines the following issues: 
1. How the literary is represented in film adaptations. 
2. How literary devices are used in cinema, and vise versa. 
3. Different modes of representation in literature and film. 
4. Narrative and perception. 
5. The question of faithfulness in film adaptations.
schedule:
I. Introduction (1 week): Narrative and the detective 
1. Akutagawa’s ‘Rashomon’ and ‘In a Bamboo Grove’ (short stories)
2. Rashomon (dir. Kurosawa)

II. Englishness in literature and film (5 weeks)
1. E. M. Foster, Howards End
2. Howards End (1992) (dir. James Ivory)
3. Kazuo Ishiguro, The Remains of the Day
4. The Remains of the Day (dir. James Ivory)

III. Shakespeare, Kurosawa, and adaptations (5 weeks)
1. Shakespeare, Macbeth
2. Film adaptation of Macbeth: Philip Cusson / Trevor Nunn’s 1979 TV adaptation 
3. Throne of Blood (1957, dir. Kurosawa)
4. Ran (1985, dir. Kurosawa)

IV. Modernist narrative and cinematic perception (5 weeks)
1. Virginia Woolf, Mrs Dalloway
2. The Hours (2002, dir. Stephen Daldry)
3. Talk to Her (2002, dir. Almod?var) – intertextuality: draws on cinema as much as on novel
scorePolicy:
Teaching Approach (tentative):

The students are expected to have read/watched the required texts before the lecture. Classes will be in the form of lectures and tutorials (2-hour lecture and 1-hour tutorial per week). Assessments include tutorial participations, presentation, mid-term test, and essay writing.

Assessment: 

Continuous Assessment
　　Tutorial participation 　　10%
　　Presentation 　　　　20%
　　Mid-term test　　　　30%
         Final Essay　　　　40% (drafts 20%, final 20%)
Total:　　　　　　　　100%
